(I am actually using this to toggle between fa-checked and fa-ban icon for an enabled/disabled toggle and I'm selecting the .enabled_domain and .disabled_domain classes, respectively)
[08:20:06] <taplar> you can do it a couple ways
[08:20:42] <taplar> you could bind on an initial class and in the handler check which class it has to know which one to remove and which one to add

[08:20:53] <taplar> or you could delegate bind both classes on a parent element

[12:00:28] <sj13> What's the difference between click and onclick functions?
[12:00:35] <Narhir> thanks guys
[12:00:38] <Narhir> you helped me a ton! :)
[12:00:44] <taplar> onclick is the dom attribute
[12:00:49] <taplar> it's outside of jquery
[12:01:06] <taplar> you want click instead of onclick for various reason
[12:01:09] <taplar> *s
[12:01:56] <sj13> So basically onclick is simply fired only when you click on that particular element?
[12:02:11] <taplar> they result in the same result
[12:02:15] <taplar> one has more constraints though
[12:02:57] <taplar> onclick is unable to do delegate binding
[12:03:11] <taplar> also using onclick is a violation of separation of concerns
[12:03:44] <taplar> and also, iirc, you cannot have onclick do multiple things
[12:03:49] <taplar> which is a scalable issue
[12:04:58] <sj13> taplar, in this particular snippet http://pastebin.com/WchNfe9u, what exactly happens when the text is changed to Goodbye and the user clicks on it again?
[12:05:34] <robertmaxrees> make a fiddle and see :)
[12:05:40] <taplar> in that snipplet i'm pretty sure that..... it doesn't exist anymore and I can't tell you
[12:07:53] <sj13> robertmaxrees, I ran the code, but I don't understand why it works that way. When the text is changed to goodbye, how is the click event being fired when onclick still specifies the same function to be called when it's clicked.
[12:08:47] <robertmaxrees> sj13 you're replacing the contents of #title, and also ADDING another event handler.
[12:10:33] <robertmaxrees> https://jsfiddle.net/robertmaxrees/2bpxau4j/ - you want to use .on()/.click(), not the dom onclick attribute.
[12:10:55] <sj13> Why is that event fired when you click the second time?
[12:11:06] <robertmaxrees> *the handler, not the evemt.
[12:11:20] <taplar> why would it not fire?
[12:11:26] <robertmaxrees> and onclick isn't impacted by .on()/.off().  don't juggle handlers anyway.
[12:11:41] <taplar> remember when i said onclick is outside jquery? ;)
[12:13:09] * taplar decides it's time to zombie walk down to the bistro while saying "fooooooood"
[12:14:08] <robertmaxrees> sj13 https://jsfiddle.net/robertmaxrees/2bpxau4j/1/ do something like this instead.  even better, hide/show things or use classes.
[12:14:48] <sj13> So when it's clicked for the first time, the handler isn't exited, then when the user clicks the second time, the click is run and then that handler is removed immediately as well, hence the when clicked again, the function is called. Is this correct?
[12:15:20] <robertmaxrees> Err.
[12:15:24] <robertmaxrees> you have two handlers.
[12:15:41] <robertmaxrees> the first one is always fired - sayGoodbye is fired every time you click that element.
[12:16:05] <robertmaxrees> the first time you click it, you also bind a second handler - the one inside that .click()
[12:16:39] <robertmaxrees> the second time you click that element, you fire sayGoodbye again, which also binds that second handler AND runs it from the last time it was bound.
[12:16:54] <robertmaxrees> when that second handler runs, it removes itself.
[12:17:20] <relipse> how do I correctly incorporate css into my jqueyr
[12:17:32] <relipse> plugin
[12:17:33] <robertmaxrees> that sentence makes no sense relipse :)
[12:17:46] <relipse> i'm just wondering how to deal with my css
[12:17:50] <relipse> that goes with my plugin
[12:18:06] <robertmaxrees> oh, add a stylesheet and require that people include it.
[12:20:01] <sj13> robertmaxrees, on the first click how's it bound but not executed? I don't understand the alternating behaviour.
[12:20:48] <robertmaxrees> $("#title").click(function () { only  binds thing.
[12:20:57] <robertmaxrees> *things - it doesn't run the handler inside of it.
[12:21:25] <robertmaxrees> brb
[12:21:57] <robertmaxrees> aaaaand back.
[12:24:20] <robertmaxrees> sj13 basically, the code you had doesn't really make sense.
[12:24:59] <sj13> robertmaxrees, so what about the  $("#title").off("click"); during the first click? Since there is no handler, there is nothing to remove? And on the second click, where and how exactly is the event fired since you said everything inside click() is responsible for binding and not running.
[12:25:10] <robertmaxrees> errr.
[12:25:17] <robertmaxrees> that part doesn't run on the first click.
[12:25:22] <sj13> It confused me so much, robertmaxrees :/
[12:25:51] <robertmaxrees> you're basically overthinking it.
[12:25:52] <robertmaxrees> back up a tick.
[12:26:13] <sj13> Basically the flow of control isn't making sense in my head at all.
[12:26:17] <robertmaxrees> the first time sayGoodbye runs, it changes the html inside an element and adds a jquery event handler.
[12:26:35] <robertmaxrees> anything inside of $("#title").click(function () { doesn't run yet because that hasn't been bound.

[12:33:34] <robertmaxrees> i think you mean querySelector or querySelectorAll

[12:34:45] <km4> hi
[12:35:05] <km4> have this problem in Chrome http://jsbin.com/wapifefoja/edit?html,css,js,console,output
[12:35:08] <robertmaxrees> for starters, getElementsByClassName isn't supported in IE 8 or lower.
[12:35:34] <robertmaxrees> sj13 but also, $() returns a jquery object, which means you get a bunch of methods and properties you don't have on raw DOM nodes.
[12:36:11] <taplar_lunch> km4:what's the problem?
[12:36:45] <km4> look console
[12:37:01] <km4> In and out the same time if I move mouse into nav
[12:37:17] <sj13> That;s pretty much what I gathered -- $() returns a jquery object so all jquery methods can be called on it directly, but not the other ones. That's about it, robertmaxrees?
[12:37:31] <robertmaxrees> "but not the other ones"?
[12:37:55] <sj13> The raw DOM nodes returned from other methods.
[12:38:00] <robertmaxrees> and $() also gives you sizzle support, so you have access to some extra selectors and cross-browser support/normalization wouldn't get otherwise.

[14:09:47] <hellyeah> typed*

[14:10:15] <robertmaxrees> though to be 100% honest you shouldn't be using jquery as a templating engine much if at all, you're adding unnecessary work.
[14:10:37] <robertmaxrees> it matters if you want your code to make sense :) jquery is going to handle creating the element in a way that supports all browsers.
[14:10:43] <hellyeah> templating engine you mean creating elements?
[14:10:51] <robertmaxrees> yes.,
[14:11:01] <hellyeah> robertmaxrees:  ic

[14:27:15] <hlvwrk> or unnecessary.

[14:27:23] <robertmaxrees> that's correct.
[14:27:27] <robertmaxrees> wait
[14:27:29] <robertmaxrees> back waaaaaaay up.
[14:27:37] <taplar> technically if it's the last statement in a {} then the ; is optional
[14:27:46] <robertmaxrees> *optional.
[14:27:53] <robertmaxrees> so there's a thing called ASI that makes all of this kind of weird.
[14:28:06] <Uhkis> also its not {} block
[14:28:08] <robertmaxrees> it dictates the rules of where the engine will insert semicolons for you if you forget them.
[14:28:28] <robertmaxrees> "optional" often means "ASI will save you", but that doesn't necessarily mean you have valid code.
[14:28:29] <arc_> if it's kind of weird and including it is not going to break anything, sounds like you should jsut include it instead of trying to learn when you can save yourself from typing one character :p
[14:28:48] <robertmaxrees> it just means "the ASI algo can generally figure out what you probably meant"
[14:28:58] <taplar> yeah.  some uglifiers will remove them though
[14:28:58] <robertmaxrees> something a lot of people (myself included) don't like to rely on.
[14:29:18] <robertmaxrees> sure, because they're minifying them.
[14:29:26] <hlvwrk> so my review comments told me to add in 'missing semicolons'
[14:29:40] <taplar> yeah which is where my statement was coming from.  but from a readability standpoint, use em
[14:29:41] <hlvwrk> so I added them in everywhere where they *could* go in, even if technically not needed.
[14:29:44] <taplar> makes it concise
[14:29:51] <robertmaxrees> hlvwrk that's a bad way to solve that problem.

[16:47:20] <robertmaxrees> you're conflating things.
[16:47:35] <robertmaxrees> .on() just binds something - that part runs whenever it runs.
[16:47:42] <claytonzaugg> yeah, it's what happens when you're not comfortable with all the things yet :)
[16:47:43] <robertmaxrees> the handler itself can run whenever.
[16:47:51] <claytonzaugg> That makes sense then.
[16:48:06] <robertmaxrees> so in this case, you want .on() to run only when the html exists, so-to-speak
